prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to create a new original text by taking inspiration from this text. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to create a new original text by taking inspiration from this text. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story:
The winner of a Xiangqi, or Chinese chess, tournament has been stripped of his title after allegations of inappropriate behaviour.

Yan Chenglong has also been accused of cheating by using a communication device analogous to anal beads.

The 48-year-old has been stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

However, the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) says it's impossible to prove accusations of cheating.

Xiangqi has been hugely popular across Asia for hundreds of years.

According to the CXA, Mr Yan started drinking with friends in his hotel room shortly after winning the title of "Xiangqi King" at a national tournament held on the Chinese island of Hainan last week.

He then defecated in the hotel bath in an act "that damaged hotel property and violated public order and good morals", said the CXA statement.

The CXA was forced to address rumours circulating online that Mr Yan had cheated using anal beads equipped with wireless transmitters to send and receive signals.

"Based on our understanding of the situation, it is currently impossible to prove that Yan engaged in cheating via 'anal beads' as speculated on social media," the CXA said.

As punishment for bad behaviour, Mr Yan was stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

The association did not disclose the amount of prize money Yan was forfeiting, but Xiangqi tournaments often promise winners tens of thousands of yuan (thousands of dollars), according to AFP.
stories:
The victor of a Go tournament has been disqualified from his title following claims of improper conduct.

Li Weihas been also accused of cheating by utilizing a communication device similar to a smartwatch.

The 39-year-old has been disqualified of his title and banned from participating for a year.

However, the Chinese Go Association (CGA) states it's impractical to prove allegations of cheating.

Go has been immensely popular across Asia for hundreds of years.

According to the CGA, Mr. Li started celebrating with friends in his hotel room shortly after winning the title of "Go King" at a national tournament held in the Chinese city of Shanghai last week.

He then urinated in the hotel sink in an act "that damaged hotel property and violated public order and good morals", said the CGA statement.

The CGA was forced to address rumors circulating online that Mr. Li had cheated using a smartwatch equipped with wireless transmitters to send and receive signals.

"Based on our understanding of the situation, it is currently impossible to prove that Li engaged in cheating via 'smartwatch' as speculated on social media," the CGA said.

As punishment for bad behavior, Mr. Li was stripped of his title and banned from participating for a year.

The association did not disclose the amount of prize money Li was forfeiting, but Go tournaments often promise winners tens of thousands of yuan (thousands of dollars), according to AFP.

A champion of the ancient board game Shogi has been dethroned and banned from competition after allegations of misconduct.

Takeshi Tanaka, a 45-year-old veteran player, has been accused of cheating by using a hidden communication device during a national tournament in Tokyo.

The Japanese Shogi Association (JSA) announced that Tanaka has been disqualified from his title and banned from participating for two years.

However, the JSA stated that it is challenging to provide evidence of cheating using a communication device.

The association did not disclose the amount of prize money Tanaka was forfeiting, but Shogi tournaments often promise winners substantial sums of money.
